description: From late Middle English comered, from Middle French camarade, from Spanish camarada or Italian camerata, from Medieval Latin *camarata, from Latin camara, camera (“a chamber”); see chamber. Compare camaraderie.

entries.meaning: A companion in battle; fellow soldier.
(communism) A fellow socialist, communist or other similarly politically aligned person.
examples: Hello, comrade. Are you going to the Communist Party meeting tonight?

entries.meaning: (communism) A non-hierarchical title, functionally similar to "Mr.", "Mrs.", "Miss", "Ms." etc, in a communist or socialist state.
examples: Comrade Lenin inspired our people to undertake great works.

verbs.description: comrade (third-person singular simple present comrades, present participle comrading, simple past and past participle comraded)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To associate with in a friendly way.
examples: But she was happy, for she was far away under another sky, and comrading again with her Rangers, and her animal friends, and the soldiers.
